text: Senator Robert Kennedy, a champion of civil rights, is shot and killed moments after leaving a rally celebrating his victory over Eugene McCarthy in the California Democratic primary.

Four hundred treaties protecting Native Americans have been broken by this year. The newly formed American Indian Movement (AIM), organized in midwestern cities by Dennis Banks, Clyde Bellecourt, and others, represents a militant voice for Native American rights. One program, modeled after the Black Panthers, monitors police. [pic: Dennis Banks]
The 24th Amendment abolishes the poll tax, which had originally been instituted in 11 southern states after Reconstruction to make it difficult for poor Blacks to vote.
James Meredith becomes the first Black student to enroll at the University of Mississippi. Violence and riots surrounding the incident cause President Kennedy to send 5,000 federal troops

The Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees is signed, defining rights of refugees, including protections for employment and welfare, on the issue of identity papers and travel documents. The Convention is amended in 1967 to apply to all people who become refugees after 1951
Cuban Refugees Airlift begins. Cubans are admitted to the U.S. under special quotas.

Alex Odeh, regional director of the American-Arab Anti Discrimination Committee on the West Coast, is killed by a bomb triggered to explode when he opens his office door in Santa Ana, California. Previously on August 16, two police were injured dismantling a bomb at the ADC office in Boston and another bomb was discovered near the home of an Arab-American physician in Cambridge, Massachusetts. On November 29, a two-alarm "suspicious" fire at the ADC headquarters in Washington DC burns out of control for 45 minutes gutting the ADC offices. No arrests are made.

The Immigration and Nationality Act (aka the Hart-Celler Act) repeals the national origins quota system that favors European migration, leading to increased immigration from Latin America, Asia, and other regions. The act is signed at the foot of the Statue of Liberty, and enacted three years later.
At least 61 violent deaths occur on the Pine Ridge reservation. Most are AIM activists or supporters. Using only the (conservative) figure of documented deaths, the death rate is 170 per 100,000.

President Johnson’s National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders (aka the Kerner Commission) reports on the causes of the civil disorders that disrupted the nation in 1967, identifying the major cause of the rioting as the existence of two separate bodies in America, “one Black, one White, separate and unequal.” It charges that White racism was the chief catalyst that ignited so many urban ghettos in 1967: “White institutions created it, White institutions maintain it, and White society condones it.” To overcome this terrible and crushing legacy, the commission implores the nation to initiate a massive and sustained commitment to action and reform, and appeals for unprecedented levels of “funding and performance” in housing, education, employment, welfare, law enforcement, and the mass media.

Basil Williams, President of the Allegany Seneca, appeals to President John F. Kennedy to stop the Kinzua Dam. His plea is ignored. The building of the dam floods ~10,000 acres of habitable Seneca lands along the Allegheny River in New York and forces 1/3 of the population to relocate, violating the government’s oldest active treaty (1794) with the Six Nations.

Nearly 800 Native American people from 90 Nations/tribes gather at the Native American Chicago Conference and prepare the Declaration of Native American Purpose addressing the inherent right of all people to retain spiritual and cultural values, and calling for action toward formulating and adopting policies and programs empowering Native American people.

A government panel releases its final report determining whether the Tuskegee Syphilis Study, conducted between 1932 and 1972 by the Public Health Service, was justified. The study involved observing the effects of untreated syphilis of 430 Black men living in rural Macon County, Alabama. The panel found no evidence that participants in the study had been given any type of informed consent. The panel concluded that the study was unjustified on both scientific and humanitarian grounds and that all policies regarding research on humans be reformed.
U.S. invades Cuba in the Bay of Pigs.
Author Alex Haley receives a Pulitzer Prize for his book Roots.

Four young girls (Denise McNair, Cynthia Wesley, Carole Robertson, and Addie Mae Collins) attending Sunday school in Birmingham, Ala. are killed when a bomb explodes at the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church, a popular location for civil rights meetings. Riots erupt in Birmingham, leading to the deaths of two more Black youths.
Student protests over the past year lead to Asian American studies programs being established at some colleges.
As more and more Puerto Ricans commit to remaining on the U.S. mainland, they encounter a great deal of rejection, but at the same time demonstrate a growing concern for social and economic mobility.
Thurgood Marshall is appointed the first Black associate justice of the United States Supreme Court.

Martin Luther King is arrested and jailed during anti-segregation protests in Birmingham, Alabama; he writes his seminal "Letter from Birmingham Jail" arguing that individuals have the moral duty to disobey unjust laws. 
King targets Birmingham for a drive against discrimination. The protesters are driven back by police armed with water hoses and attack dogs. The confrontation, which has been captured on film, awakens public opinion across the country.

The "Magnuson Act” finally repeals the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882. This was a direct result of the alliance between the United States and China during World War II. A quota of 105 per year set for Chinese immigration (based on a formula set at one-sixth the total population of that ancestry in the 1920 census).

In Lac Court Oreilles Band of Chippewa Indians v. Lester P. Voigt et al the U.S. 7th Circuit Court of Appeals (Chicago) finds that the 1854 treaty did not end Ojibwe rights to hunt and fish on the territory they ceded. The U.S. Supreme Court refuses to hear the appeal by the State of Wisconsin, thereby leaving the decision standing and the rights intact.
CORE stages its first “sit-in” in at a Chicago restaurant.

The U.S. secretly invades Cambodia as a strategy to destroy Viet Cong hideouts and supports. Over the next four years, literally tons of U.S. bombs are dropped on Cambodian villages and cities along the South Vietnam-Cambodia border, killing and injuring civilians with no formal declaration of war against Cambodia.

The Council of Federated Organizations (COFO), a network of civil rights groups that includes CORE and SNCC, launches a massive effort to register Black voters during what becomes known as the Freedom Summer.

Hearing the case University of California v. Bakke, the United States Supreme Court, in a 5 to 4 decision, orders that White student Allan P. Bakke be admitted to the medical school at the University of California, Davis. The Court rules that the refusal to admit Bakke is tantamount to reverse discrimination and that the use of racial or ethnic quotas is an improper means of achieving racial balance. The Court also holds that the college’s affirmative action program is invalid, since it had the effect of discriminating against qualified White applicants, although the Court perceived the goal of attaining a diverse student body constitutional and permissible.

The “zoot-suit” riots are the worst race riots in Los Angeles to date and continue for 10 nights. American sailors target young Mexican Americans dressed in baggy paints and long-tailed coats (zoot-suiters), tearing off their clothes and beating them.

The U.S. and Mexican governments institute the Bracero program. Thousands of impoverished Mexican farm workers abandon their rural communities and head north to the southwestern part of the U.S. to work the fields once harvested by Americans now off to war. The Bracero could return to their native lands in case of an emergency, only with written permission from their boss. When their contract expired, the Bracero were required to turn in their permits and return to Mexico. The Bracero Program brings in over 5 million temporary workers from Mexico who help fill the agricultural labor shortage, but also bring farming techniques and knowledge. The Bracero suffer harassment and oppression from extremist groups and racist authorities.
More than 250,000 Cubans are airlifted to the U.S. Congress passes the Cuban American Adjustment Act allowing Cubans who lived in America for at least one year to become permanent residents.

CORE begins sending student volunteers on bus trips to test the implementation of new laws prohibiting segregation in interstate travel facilities. One of the first two groups of "freedom riders," as they are called, encounters its first problem two weeks later, when a mob in Alabama sets the riders' bus on fire. The program continues, and by the end of the summer 1,000 volunteers, Black and White, have participated.
The Navajo Community College on the Navajo Reservation in Arizona becomes the first 4-year college established and controlled by a Native American Nation/tribe.
Yoko Ono marries John Lennon
General DeWitt testifies that “A Jap’s a Jap. You can’t change him by giving him a piece of paper”. In stark contrast to his previous citizenship statement.

The McCarran-Walter Immigration & Nationality Act goes into effect, repealing the National Origins Act of 1924 and allowing immigration quotas to Japan and other Asian countries, conferring rights of naturalization and eventual citizenship for immigrant Asians. The McCarren-Walter Act eliminates racial barriers to citizenship, but also tightens quotas for immigrants and allows deportation of immigrant for “subversive activities.”

In the East Room of the White House, Arapaho Chief Sharp Nose presents a pipe and tobacco pouch to President Rutherford Hayes. This was President Hayes's first meeting with a Native American delegation, which consisted of three Arapaho and twenty Sioux people.

The National Network for Arab American Communities is formed due to 9/11 backlash against Arab Americans, with the goal of understanding their needs and concerns at a local and national levels. The NNAAC grows to 24 member organizations in eleven different states including California, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, Minnesota, Florida, Georgia, Texas, Illinois, Ohio and Pennsylvania. The NNAAC becomes a program of ACCESS.
The Arab American National Museum opens in Dearborn Michigan, the first museum in the United States devoted to the history, culture and contributions of Arab Americans from 1500 to the present day.
UCLA professor and Asian American activist, Yuji Ichioka dies. He is credited with coining the term “Asian American.”

The Page Law prohibits entry of Chinese, Japanese, and “Mongolian” prostitutes. The law requires proof of “good character” for entry and is widely applied to all Chinese women, contributing to a gender imbalance that reaches a ratio of 27 Chinese men to every one Chinese woman in the U.S. by 1890.

904 charges are filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) alleging post-September 11-backlash discrimination. The charges in this category include national origin discrimination claims by an individual who are or who are perceived to be Muslim, Arab, Afghani, Middle Eastern or South Asian or individuals alleging retaliation related to the terror events.
President Bill Clinton posthumously presents César Chavez with the Medal of Freedom, America's highest civilian honor.
Hurricane Katrina causes severe destruction, injuries, and death in U.S. Gulf Coast area affecting the large Vietnamese and Vietnamese American population there.
American Civil War. Hostilities begin when seceded slave states (grouped together as the Confederate States of America) fire on Fort Sumter in Charleston, South Carolina.

Marc Anthony, the top selling salsa artist, sings “God Bless America” at the MLB All Star games. This sparked Twitter rants with racial epithets claiming that Anthony is not actually an American, despite the fact he was born and raised in New York.

Hurricane Katrina devastates New Orleans and other parts of the South exposing issues of racism and classism in protective measures, emergency response to victims and reconstruction efforts. National television coverage portrays images that mirror those of third world countries.
Ming Sun is first Chinese immigrant with the U.S. forces killed in Iraq War. His parents are presented with a Bronze Star, a Purple Heart and papers granting him citizenship.

Booker T. Washington states social reality: "It is a fact that, if a person is known to have one percent of African blood in his veins, he ceases to be a White man. The ninety-nine percent of Caucasian blood does not weigh by the side of the one percent of African blood. The White blood counts for nothing. The person is a Negro every time."

Gary Locke is inaugurated governor of Washington – the first Chinese American governor in the United States. In 2009 he serves as the United States Secretary of Commerce, and in 2011 he becomes the first Chinese American to serve as ambassador to China.
Congress passes a bill authorizing equal pay, equipment, arms, and health care for African American troops.

The United States Supreme Court rules that the 14th Amendment insures Blacks all rights that are enjoyed by Whites under law. In a separate case, the Court rules that one of the purposes of both the 13th and 14th Amendments is to raise the condition of Blacks to one of perfect equality with Whites.
Native American units fought on both sides during the Civil War
During the civil war, Mulattos form a Negro regiment to defend Louisiana but are disarmed by White officers.
The Carta Autonómica is approved in Spain, granting autonomy and home rule to Cuba and Puerto Rico.

Due to an increase in profiling and discrimination against Muslims and South Asian people, the Proteus Fund creates the Security and Rights Collaborative. Their goal is to build national security as well as support the human rights of the community affected.

In the first month after the 9/11 attacks, the Sikh Coalition documents over 300 cases of violence and discrimination against Sikh Americans throughout the United States. Sikhs practice a different religion than Muslims but due to the Sikh turban, beard, and appearing ‘brown’, which are some characteristics these two groups share, people often misidentify and conflate the two groups together. The victims of this violence are not limited to one nationality or religion.
The Boston Chinese Immigrant Memorial is completed and dedicated in Mount Hope Cemetery in Mattapan.
Ali Almansoop, a U.S. citizen of Yemeni descent, is shot in the back while escaping from his attacker who had broken into his home in Lincoln Park, Michigan.
13% of Asian Americans are living at poverty level.  An increase of 10% from 2007.
Congress debates legislation to criminalize undocumented immigrants.
White miners in Rock Springs, Wyoming kill at least 28 Chinese miners and burn 75 Chinese homes.
1% of the U.S. population is considered Asian/Pacific Islander – 87.9% is considered white

Kamehameha Schools defends its "Hawaiians-only" admissions policy against a lawsuit by a non-Hawaiian. In November, District Judge Alan Cooke Kay dismisses the lawsuit finding that the policy serves a "legitimate, remedial purpose by improving native Hawaiians' socioeconomic and educational disadvantages". In 2005, the ruling is reversed by the 9th Circuit of Appeals. Kamehameha lawyers describe the ruling as "unprecedented" noting “it is the first in our nation's history to invalidate a remedial education policy by a private school for the benefit of any minority group, much less an indigenous people." The ruling is followed by large protests prompting the 9th Circuit to re-hear the appeal en banc in 2006, after which they restore the original ruling. The case is then appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court but settled before being heard for $7 million. Attorneys Eric Grant and David Rosen file another suit against Kamehameha the same day on behalf of four other non-Hawaiian students.
Immigration raids and deportation cases significantly increase, affecting Latino individual, families, and communities across the United States.

The “Gentleman’s Agreement”. President Theodore Roosevelt seeks to limit Japanese immigration without angering Japan. Japan agrees to not to issue passports for Japanese citizens wishing to work in the continental United States, and United States agrees to accept the presence of Japanese immigrants already residing in America, and to permit the immigration of wives, children and parents, and to avoid legal discrimination against Japanese American children in California schools. Executive Order 589 restricts citizens of Japan and Korea from entering the continental U.S. via Mexico, Canada or Hawaii. In exchange for the intervention in the school segregation case, Japan does not protest the Executive Order.

Tony Shalhoub, a Lebanese American, is the leading character named Adrian Monk in the TV show “Monk”. Shalhoub also plays roles in Men in Black and Men in Black II. The series makes him a star and earns him four straight Emmy Award nominations between 2003 and 2006, for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series which he wins in 2003, 2005 and 2006.
Congress enacts the American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act in an effort to correct the long record of disregard for the rights, and funds of Native American tribal members.
Middle-class White Protestant women set up rescue homes for Chinese women who had been brought to California and forced to work as prostitutes.
The attacks on the World Trade Center on 9/11 results in increasing fears about border security. Some politicians call for building a wall between the United States and Mexico.
Chiricahua Apache leader Geronimo surrenders after 15 years.

Donna Shalala becomes the first Arab American appointed to a Cabinet post, and becomes the longest serving Secretary of Health and Human Services, serving for all 8 years of the Clinton administration. She goes on to become President of the University of Miami and receives numerous awards including the Medal of Freedom and the Nelson Mandela Award.
Violent attacks on Chinese communities in Washington territory in Seattle, Tacoma and Issaquah (then known as Squak).

Preventing Violent Extremism (aka "Prevent") is launched in the United Kingdom, targeting Muslims who are perceived as being radicalized through actions such as wearing a headscarf, having a beard, or praying five times a day; all of which are basic principles in Islam. U.S. government officials partner with local police, schools, and hospitals to build Countering Violent Extremism (CVE) programs that threaten American Muslims’ religious self-determination and may violate First Amendment rights by targeting and surveilling people who express criticism towards U.S. policies. Lack of government transparency and accountability, heavy focus on gathering intelligence on Muslim communities and the policing of radical dissent result in diminished youth confidence in democracy. Prevent has also compromised Muslims’ ability to safely use social services, as its “Channel Program” has been extended to the health sector, eroding practices of doctor-patient confidentiality.
The Geary Act extends the Chinese Exclusion Act, denying bail and writ of habeas corpus, and requiring Chinese living in the U.S. to carry certificates of residence.
Dr. Joycelyn Elders becomes the first African American appointed as Surgeon General of the United States.
Federal policy forbids Native American language books or instruction.
The ringleader of the Mississippi civil rights murders, Edgar Ray Killen, is convicted of manslaughter on the 41st anniversary of the crimes.
Cherokee land in Indiana is opened for settlement.
The U.S. government again breaks treaty with the Sioux to reduce the Sioux Reservation to about 1/5 its original size.
The Chicago Palestinian Film Festival begins in response to the absence of positive media about Palestinians. Over the next several years, annual Palestinian film festivals in other cities begin.

President Bush authorizes the Military Commissions Act, further subjecting Guantanamo Bay detainees to laws that significantly deviate from the traditional U.S. standards of justice. By December, over 750 individuals all labeled ‘enemy combatants’ are being held on the base without having been tried or even formally charged.

The U.S. government implements a blockade strategy along the U.S. Mexico border, forcing migrants to cross through the desert: Operation Gatekeeper (CA), Operation Safeguard (AZ), and Operation Blockade/Hold The Line (TX). Over the next decade, over 3,000 people die while trying to cross the border.
Publication of the poem “The Heathen Chinese” highlighted tensions between Irish and Chinese, and the reality of racism.

A joint resolution is passed by Congress to acknowledge the 100th anniversary of the overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii and to formally apologize to the Native Hawaiians for depriving them of their rights.
63,199 Chinese in continental U.S., 99.4% in western states/territories, 78% in California.
The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Reform Act increases the number of border patrol agents, and creates a centralized database for immigration and law enforcement.

Congress amends naturalization requirements to exclude Chinese, extending eligibility to "aliens being free white persons, and to aliens of African nativity and to persons of African descent". Nationwide recession causes West Coast labor problems. Mobs destroy Chinese communities in many areas of California and other states.
In the census, Mulattos are officially defined to include "quadroons, octoroons, and all persons having any perceptible trace of African blood."

According to the organization South Asian American Leaders of Tomorrow (SAALT), 645 bias incidents were reported in metropolitan newspapers across the country in the week after 9/11. Many Arab and Muslim American individuals and organizations received threats, Arab Americans were denied entry on planes and had home loan applications rejected.
Actor, director and screenwriter, Tyler Perry becomes first African American to own a major film and television studio

The United States Supreme Court rules that the Civil Rights Act of 1875, forbidding discrimination in hotels, trains, and other public spaces, was unconstitutional and not authorized by the 13th or 14th Amendments.
By 1900, the mestizos (Spanish and Native American heritage) have become the largest ethnic group in Mexico.

Sitting Bull, a Lakota chief, is killed by Native American Police under the direction of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. His people flee their homes for Pine Ridge Agency to counsel with Red Cloud and others. In December, they are intercepted by the Seventh Cavalry and forced to camp at Wounded Knee Creek. Nearly 300 Lakota are murdered, mostly women, children, elders. This is the last of the outright massacres. The U.S. awards Medals of Honor to at least 20 soldiers for this action.

The Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) Movement is formed to increase political and economic pressure for Israel to end its occupation of Palestinian land and grant equality to Arab-Palestinian citizens of Israel.
U.S. government establishes Native American police forces for reservation supervision.

California imposes a Foreign Miner’s License Tax, collecting $3 a month from every foreign miner who is not a citizen. At this time Chinese were prohibited from citizenship by law, and the purpose of this tax is to reduce the number of Chinese immigrating to California and discouraging Chinese from mining for gold.
Waqar Hasan, a Pakistani, is shot dead in his grocery store by Mark Anthony Stroman, a white supremacist, in Dallas, Texas.

Following the Chinese Exclusion Act, large numbers of young Japanese laborers, together with smaller numbers of Koreans and Indians began arriving on the West Coast where they replace the Chinese as cheap labor in building railroads, farming and fishing.

The San Francisco School Board creates an international incident when it orders school principles to send “all Chinese, Japanese and Korean children to the newly formed Oriental School.” The previous year, U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt had mediated the Treaty of Portsmouth, formally ending the Russo-Japanese War in which the Empire of Japan defeated the Empire of Russia. In November, the School Board removes 93 children of Japanese ancestry (25 U.S. citizens) to the segregated school.

Captain Richard Henry Pratt founds Carlisle Native American School in Pennyslvania.  The aim of the school is to immerse Native Americans in European American culture. During vacations Pratt sends students to live and work with white families to increase assimilation.

Disney releases cartoon Mulan, who became the first Asian Disney princess. The issue with Mulan’s character illustrates Disney’s version of the stereotype “yellow peril” which is common in Hollywood stereotypes surrounding the Asian American community. While Mulan is depicted as a strong woman character, she is a whitewashed version of an Asian girl, growing up in Ancient China. Since the movie is the only example of an Asian princess, it leaves young girls confused about having this one limited “role model” to look up to.
Congress passes the Fugitive Slave Act, which makes it a criminal offense to harbor a slave, or prevent his or her arrest.
The University of California votes to eliminate affirmative action policies in the admission of students.
The Clinton administration and Democratic National Committee are involved in scandal because of an alleged plan by China to influence the U.S. government through campaign donations.
U.S. reaches agreement with Vietnam to allow political prisoners to emigrate to the U.S.

Second Seminole War (aka the Florida War). The longest and most costly conflict between the United States and Native Americans. The United States ultimately succeeds in forcing the Seminole from their land.

President George Bush vetoes the Civil Rights Act of 1990. On October 16, the Senate passes the bill by a vote of 62 to 34; the House of Representatives passes the bill on October 17, by a 273 to 154 vote. The legislation is designed to reverse the Court’s 1989 decision in the case of Wards Cove Packing Co. v. Antonio, which made it more difficult for minorities and women to prove job discrimination. Bush cites his fear of the introduction of quotas in the workplace as his reason for rejecting the act. On October 24, an attempt to override the veto in the Senate falls one vote short of the two-thirds majority needed.
groups: Native American,African American,Latino/as,Asian American,Middle East/North Africa,Multiracial

text: Penobscot and Passamaquoddy Nations/tribes oblige the federal government to bring a land claim on their behalf for approximately 60% of the state of Maine.

A study conducted by the Federal Reserve’s regional bank shows evidence of bank discrimination against minorities applying for mortgages. The study measures Black, Hispanic, and White rejection rates when all applicants had similar application criteria. The findings show 17 percent rejection of minorities compared to 11 percent rejection of Whites.
Virginia draws a genetic line, legally defining a Negro as a person with a Black parent or grandparent.

Start of attacks against persons who only appear, at least to some Americans, to be Middle Eastern, Arab, or Muslim. People who “appear” Muslim have also been attacked even though Muslims are found among all races, ethnic groups, and nationalities. In the context of U.S. hate-violence, however, “Muslim” has been equated with Middle Eastern or Arab. Sikh men who wear turbans have also been lumped with “Arab” terrorists and victimized. In short, a confluence of events in U.S. history leads to the construction of a new racial stereotype and target for bias, fear, and hate crimes: persons who are or appear to be “Middle Eastern, Arab or Muslim.”

Building on their successful bingo operation, the Mashantucket Pequot open Foxwoods Casino, generating enough revenue to become the wealthiest group of Native Americans in the United States. Part of the revenues are used to create the Pequot Museum, providing historical detail and insight into Pequot history.
Overriding President Reagan’s veto, Congress passes the Civil Rights Restoration Act, which expands the reach of non-discrimination laws within private institutions receiving federal funds.
Mulatto is provided as a category on the census, but is not defined as a term.

Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Cuban American, becomes the first Latino woman elected to the U.S. House of Representatives. Consistently re-elected, she rises to become the most senior U.S. Representative from Florida.

The Louisiana Purchase. Having regained ownership of the area in 1800, Napoleon sells the territory to U.S. for $15 million. The territory includes what is now Louisiana west of the Mississippi River (plus New Orleans), Arkansas, Missouri, Iowa, Oklahoma, Kansas, and Nebraska. It also includes parts of Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, New Mexico, Texas, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, and small portions of land within the present Canadian provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan. The U.S. borders now connect directly with New Spain.
The Constitution is adopted. In it, importation of slaves cannot be prohibited before 1808, and five slaves are considered the equivalent of three free men in congressional apportionment.
First U.S. Naturalization Act allows only “free white persons” to become American citizens.
Congress bars the importation of any new slaves into the U.S. The law is widely ignored.
TIME Magazine publishes cover article entitled “Those Asian-American Whiz Kids.” Many Chinese Americans express concern about a “model minority” stereotype.

WDET-FM National Public Radio disseminates Arab culture programming across America. Arabesque: Insights into Arab Culture seeks to portray a positive image of the Arab American Community. Jack Shaheen, Professor of Communication at Southern Illinois University and author of numerous articles and books on the Arab stereotype in mass media, announces the national satellite distribution.
Lauro Fred Cavazos becomes is appointed Secretary of Education by President Ronald Reagan, becoming the first Hispanic to serve in the United States Cabinet.

The American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee is founded in Washington, D.C. by former U.S. Senator James Abourezk. In an attempt to inform the Arab and American public about anti-Arab propaganda, the ADC announces its winter program to combat media stereotyping and discrimination against Americans of Arab descent.
Civil rights activist Rosa Parks is beaten and robbed in her home.
The American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee announces a national campaign to protest ABC-TV’s clear anti-Arab bias in news reporting and feature programs.
Massachusetts and Vermont state legislatures defy the Fugitive Slave Act and forbid state officials from imprisoning or assisting federal authorities in the recapture of escaped slaves.
Jefferson dies, emancipating only 5 of his slaves.

Luiz Villalona-Perez files a petition in Massachusetts for political asylum from the Dominican Republic on the grounds that he would be imprisoned or killed there for his homosexuality. He is backed by human rights groups.
The KKK of Texas burns boats symbolizing their opposition to Vietnamese refugee resettlement programs.

The Bureau of Indian Affairs is created (without authorization from the United States Congress) by Secretary of War John C. Calhoun as a division within his department. Through the late 19th and early 20th century native children are educated in separate assimilation boarding schools prohibiting them from using their indigenous languages, practices, and cultures.

A bill which prohibits the use of numerical quotas devised to increase the hiring or school enrollment of minorities and women is introduced. Entitled the “Equal Employment Opportunity Act,” it seeks to amend the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and prevents the federal government from imposing rules on employers or schools to hire workers or to admit students on the basis of race, sex, or national origin. In effect, the proposal no longer requires companies and educational institutions to make up for past discrimination by taking on a set number of minorities and women within a specified time frame.

President Ford signs the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, which mandates that the federal government permit Native Americans to administer their own federal programs if they desire to do so. For example, Native American people could now operate their own schools. The act reverses the termination policy.
First U.S. census notation of Chinese in America—the count is 3.
A national Asian/Pacific American movement to unify all Asian Americans begins.

The California Gold Rush further reduces the Native American population from 150,000 (half the population before white contact) to 30,000.  Native Americans are exploited as mine labor and murdered for racial and economic motives.  Many die from disease or starve to death with the destruction of their food supply by hunting and mining.  Others are driven away.  Before the Gold Rush, Native Americans outnumbered whites by nearly ten to one.
Violence erupts between supporters and opponents of public school integration. Boston busing reaches national attention, and white flight to the suburbs accelerates.
Texas is officially annexed to the U.S.
Hate crimes against Arab Americans increase after the U.S. and Allied Forces launch a war against Iraq’s military, cities, and infrastructure, in efforts to liberate Kuwait.

The Department of Justice releases memos revealing that in the 1960’s and early 1970’s, the Federal Bureau of Investigation had waged a campaign designed to disrupt, discredit, and neutralize Black nationalist groups, including the Black Panther Party. A major objective of the effort, according to the memo, was to prevent the emergence of a Black leader capable of uniting disparate factions and inspiring violence. Reverend Jesse Jackson remarks that the documents implicate the FBI in the deaths of the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Malcolm X, and Fred Hampton. [pic: Fred Hampton]

California Gold Rush.  Chinese begin to arrive, some as indentured servants. The bulk of these immigrants later become a source of cheap labor for railroads, mines, fisheries, farms, and other industries.
Dr. David Ho is named TIME Magazine Man of the Year for his research into HIV/Aids

Adams–Onís Treaty (aka the Transcontinental Treaty or the Florida Purchase Treaty). Spain sells Florida to the United States for $5 million, paid through settling legal claims of American citizens against Spain. John Quincy Adams is in a strong negotiating position with Luis de Onís as Andrew Jackson already controls two Spanish forts taken in the First Seminole War.
According to the first census, there are 757,000 Blacks in the U.S., comprising 19% of the total population. 9% of Blacks are free.

The Amerasian Homecoming Act offers top-priority U.S. immigration to children in Korea, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, or Thailand who are known to have been fathered by U.S. citizens. The act does not grant admission to mothers or other relatives.
The Million Man March, organized by the Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan, draws African American men to the nation’s capital.

The Equal Educational Opportunity Act makes bilingual education available to Hispanic youth. According to the framers of the act, equal education means more than equal facilities and equal access to teachers. Students who have trouble with the English language must be given programs to help them learn English.
First recorded arrival of Asian Indians in the U.S.

South Vietnam surrenders to the Communist forces of the North. The U.S. evacuates Vietnam, leaving approximately 30,000 American children behind. The U.S. lacks policies to deal with the Amerasians fathered by U.S. servicemen, and demonstrates no intention of recognizing the children, in stark contrast to the French response in 1954 after the first Indochina war. France allowed repatriation of all Eurasians (~25,000), providing repatriation travel, educational opportunities, and citizenship at age 18.  Amerasian children endure severe trauma and persecution in Asian home countries.
Eli Whitney patents the cotton gin, which strengthens slavery by increasing the profits of growing cotton.

Results from a nationwide survey sponsored by the National Science Foundation reveal that White Americans continue to hold negative stereotypes of Blacks and Hispanics. Three-quarters of the Whites surveyed felt that Blacks and Hispanics are more likely to prefer welfare to work. A Census Bureau report shows the household worth of White families average eight times that of Hispanic households and ten times that of Black households.

Northwest Indian War. Nations/tribes in Ohio led by Miami chief Little Turtle win decisive battles against General Josiah Harmar and General Arthur Saint Clair. Washington then orders General "Mad" Anthony Wayne to organize and train a new fighting force that defeats the nations/tribes, forcing them to cede extensive territory, including Chicago, Detroit, Toledo and much of present-day Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville. The Native Americans receive $20,000 worth of goods and the promise of $9,500 in annuities. Alcohol, hunger, and the threat of military force hasten the Native Americans’ decision.

In Wygant v. Jackson Board of Education the U.S. Supreme Court (in the first of three major affirmative action decisions) rules 5 to 4 that broad affirmative action plans including hiring goals are permissible if carefully tailored to remedy past discrimination. In a ruling involving teachers laid off in Jackson, Michigan, the court sends a mixed signal by deciding that public employers cannot give affirmative action plans as a substitute for seniority when reducing their work forces.

California voters pass Proposition 227, which bans bilingual classroom education and English as a second language programs, replacing them with a one-year intensive English immersion program. A federal judge denies challenges to the proposal and Proposition 227 goes into effect in California schools.

Segregation increases. New York grants schools the right to segregate education. South Carolina forbids White and Black mill hands from looking out the same window. Whites and Blacks in Atlanta are required to swear on different Bibles in court.

In an attempt to counter the increasing strength of the abolitionists, a number of states pass laws restricting the education, legal safeguards, and citizenship rights of slaves and free Blacks. Many states require the deportation of free Blacks, slave codes are enforced more strictly, and the number of slave emancipations declines.
The African Methodist Episcopal Church is organized in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
President Clinton issues an Executive Order on Native American Sacred Sites to affirm the American Indian Religious Freedom Act policy and protection of Native American sacred sites.
Cuban and Puerto Rican tabaqueros work in Boston in the 19th century as shop owners, factory, and farm workers. The South End Latino community is largely a bachelor society.
In Lau v. Nichols, the Supreme Court rules that failure to provide adequate education for non-English speaking students violates the Equal Protection Clause of the Constitution
Mississippi enacts a law prohibiting the teaching of reading and writing to Blacks and meetings of more than 5 slaves or free Blacks.
The quota for immigration from Hong Kong is raised from 600 to 5,000 a year.

Intimidation and cross-burning by the Ku Klux Klan in the Black ghetto of Miami fails to discourage over 1,000 of the city’s registered Blacks from appearing at the polls. The Klan parades with effigies of Blacks who will allegedly be slain for daring to vote.

Further investigation of Ferguson Missouri’s crimes over the past two years shows that black people were being targeted. 85% of traffic stops, 90% of tickets issued, and 93% of arrests were of African American citizens. Even in jaywalking incidents, African Americans made up 90% of the violation population.
The Pew Research Center reports that 55% of multiracial adults report having experienced racial slurs or jokes.

Canyon County high school in Orange County was investigated after claims of “Senores and Senoritas” day is offensive. Students come dressed as stereotypical Latino roles, which include gang members, gardeners/housekeeping staff, and border patrol who “went around campus and arrested Mexican Students.”
The National Urban League is founded in New York City. The mission of the league is "to enable African Americans to secure economic self-reliance, parity, power and civil rights."
Avril Lavigne releases Hello Kitty, a music video featuring stereotyped Japanese girls as accessories and backdrops to Lavigne as she belts out words such as “kawaii” and “arigato”.
Poet and Author Maya Angelou dies.

Four Black students from North Carolina Agricultural and Technical College begin a sit-in at a segregated Woolworth's lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina. Although they are refused service, they are allowed to stay at the counter. The event triggers many similar nonviolent protests throughout the South. Six months later, the original four protesters are served lunch at the same Woolworth's counter. Student sit-ins become effective throughout the Deep South in integrating parks, swimming pools, theaters, libraries, and other public facilities.
George H. White elects not to seek a third congressional term. No African American will serve in Congress for the next 28 years.
An Amendment to the 1945 War Brides Act allows Chinese American veterans to bring brides into the U.S.
President Barack Obama issues a statement on the murders of Yusor Salha, Razan Salha, and Deah Barakat.

New Mexico enters the union as an officially bilingual state, authorizing funds for voting in both Spanish and English, as well as for bilingual education. Article XII of the state constitution also prohibits segregation for children of "Spanish descent". At the state's constitutional convention six years earlier, Mexican American delegates mandated Spanish and English be used for all state business.

Congress passes Public Law 280, empowering any state legislature to take over civil and criminal jurisdiction on Native American reservations without tribal consent, ending Native Americans’ authority to police themselves.

Dr. Jokichi Takamine isolates pure epinephrine (adrenalin) at John Hopkins University. A long time resident of the U.S., Dr. Takamine declines honorary citizenship until all immigrants of Japanese ancestry are allowed the right to become citizens.
In Morgan v. Virginia the United States Supreme Court rules that segregation on interstate buses is unconstitutional.
The U.S. controls 44% of the cultivated land in Puerto Rico. U.S. capitalists control 60% of the banks and public services, and all of the maritime lines.
The Luce-Celler Bill is signed into law granting right of naturalization and small immigration quotas to Asian Indian and Filipinos (100 a year)
The Department of Defense reports the end of “all-Negro” units in the Army. However, some bases still refuse to integrate.

Mayor Marty Walsh announces that the city of Boston will be receiving a $17.7 million grant from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security through the Urban Area Security Initiative (UASI) grant program. "Whether natural or man-made, emergencies can happen anytime. This funding allows us to enhance the capabilities of our first responders, ensuring they are trained and prepared for any potential emergency or disaster," said Rene Fielding, OEM Director. The UASI program funding is meant to address the unique multi-disciplinary planning, organization, equipment, training and exercise needs of high-threat, high-density urban areas, and assist them in building capabilities to prevent, protect against, respond to, and recover from threats or acts of terrorism. The City of Boston was designated as an UASI site in 2003.
Japanese picture brides begin to arrive in the U.S., continuing until 1921, when U.S. convinces Japanese government to stop issuing passports.

Obama speaks with 20,000 other people to commemorate the 50 years since Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s march in Selma, Alabama. In his speech, Obama explained that African Americans have come a long way but “the march isn’t finished yet.”
The U.S. census drops Mulatto as a category. Black is defined to mean any person with any Black ancestry. This definition continues until the 2000 Census.

35 men are still imprisoned at Guantanamo after being cleared for release, and the number of prisoners the U.S. has said it lacks evidence to prosecute but claims are too dangerous to release is 28.  It costs approximately $454 million per year to keep Guantánamo open.
Approximately 20% of the Puerto Ricans living in the U.S. return to the island.
The Pentagon has spent over $5.24 billion on Guantanamo Bay Detention Camp so far.
Los Angeles Superior Court rules that Filipinos are members of the “Mongolian” race, opening the way to invalidate more than 100 interracial marriages performed since 1921.
The War department revokes the West Coast exclusion order against Japanese Americans.

The U.S. Census Bureau announces it will begin testing of a Middle East and North Africa (MENA) category in 2015 for possible inclusion on the 2020 Census. At the meeting of the National Advisory Committee, the Bureau states they have received a record number of positive comments in response to the Federal Register posting announcing the testing of the category.
Takao Ozawa, a Japanese immigrant, challenges the Supreme Court saying he qualifies for citizenship. His case is denied because he is not “Caucasian.”
Despite efforts by some enlightened naval officers, over 90 percent of Blacks in the Navy are still messmen when World War II ends.

General DeWitt, head of the Western Defense Command, rejects interning Japanese Americans by stating: “An American citizen, after all, is an American citizen.” Two years later he changes his mind. Massive voluntary enlistment of Asian Americans into U.S. armed forces begins

Latinos make up 10% of the electorate for the first time, having increased 26% over four years. The need for immigration reform is a central issue differentiating the Republicans and Democrats. Latinos voted for Obama over Romney 71% to 27%.

The report “Black Girls Matter: Pushed Out, Overpoliced and Underprotected” is issued by the African American Policy Forum and Columbia Law School’s Center for Intersectionality and Social Policy Studies. Analyzing data from from New York City and Boston school districts, it finds that 12% of black girls are subjected to suspension compared to 2% of white girls, and 90% of all female students that experienced expulsion were black.

Take On Hate, a multi-year campaign is established. Its purpose is to challenge this country’s growing prejudice and stereotypes of Arab and Muslim Americans, including refugees of Arab and Muslim descent. The organization is led by the National Network for Arab American Communities (NNAAC).
Wataru "Wat" Misaka is drafted by the New York Knicks in the first round. He is the first person of color to play in the NBA.
The Muslim Justice League (MJL) is founded in Boston to defend human and civil rights against erosion in the ongoing ‘war on terror’.
It is estimated that at least 30,0000 GIs of Arab heritage fought for the United States against Hitler, Mussolini, and General Tojo of Japan.

Bank of America is fined for discriminating against African American job candidates. 1,100 African Americans were refused various positions in the company over the years 1993-2005, in Charlotte North Carolina.
The first study on passing is done by Dr. Charles B. Davenport.
The Wilson administration begins government-wide segregation of work places, rest rooms and lunch rooms.

The League of United Latin American Citizens is established in Corpus Christi, Texas by Hispanic veterans of World War I and others seeking to end ethnic discrimination. The mission of LULAC is "to advance the economic condition, educational attainment, political influence, housing, health and civil rights of the Hispanic population of the United States."
President Truman pardons all 267 Japanese American draft resisters.
The 442nd rescues 211 soldiers of the Texas “Lost Battalion” after 5 days of fighting. The 442nd suffers over 800 casualties, including 184 dead.
A law sponsored by City Councilmember Margaret Chin allows New Yorkers to identify as more than one race, and to check more than one box on citywide documents.

The Munson report is submitted to the White House, certifying that Japanese Americans possess an extraordinary degree of loyalty to the U.S. and that immigrant Japanese are of no danger to the country. Years of secret surveillance by the FBI and office of Naval Intelligence corroborates the report.

The Jones Act. President Woodrow Wilson imposes U.S. citizenship on Puerto Ricans to increase the pool of inductees for World War I. The act creates two Puerto Rican houses of legislature whose representatives are elected by the people. English is decreed the official language of Puerto Rico.

The Great Depression. Many Mexican workers are displaced by the dominant southern whites and blacks of the migrant agricultural labor force. Thousands of Mexicans, including many U.S. citizens, are deported to Mexico. Mexican immigration to the U.S. virtually ceases and return migration increases sharply.

Hawkins v. Board of Control. The United States Supreme Court rules that a graduate professional school of a State (in this case the University of Florida) must admit Blacks regardless of “public mischief” it might cause.

United States Department of Interior begins implementing termination and relocation phases of Indian Reorganization Act of 1934. Among other effects, the termination results in the legal dismantling of 61 tribal nations within the United States.

Arizona passes a law that allows police officers to check immigration status of any Latino that they suspect may be illegal. Supporters of the law claim that the law allows regulation of illegal immigration. Human rights advocates express that the law is just allowing police officers to racial/ethnically profile Hispanics. The law creates tension between Hispanics and local law enforcement.

The Pueblo Rebellion, incited by eighty years of harsh treatment by the Spanish, results in the massacre of over four hundred soldiers, officers, and priests. The Southwest reverts to Native American country until it is reconquered 12 years later.

Immigration from the Americas rises from 44.3% in 1964 to 61.4%. Of the major countries, Mexico accounts for 37.1% of total documented immigration, the next highest number of immigrants is 5.4% from El Salvador.
Colin Powell is selected by President George H. W. Bush as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the first African American to serve in the highest military position in the Department of Defense.

The median income of Hispanic families below the poverty level falls from $7,238 in 1978 to $6,557 in 1987, controlling for inflation. The proportion of Hispanic children living in poverty rises by more than 45%.

Pequot War. Fur trade control conflicts (between English, Mohegan, Narragansett and others against Dutch, Pequot and others) escalate through murders and raids to an attack on one of the Pequot fortified villages in Mystic CT. Of the 500 Pequots there, 7 are taken prisoner and 7 escape. In the end only about 200 Pequots survive the war.
Interracial marriages begin to boom, as do multiracial offspring.
Miami's Coral Way Elementary School offers the nation's first bilingual education program in public schools with funding from the Ford Foundation.

Teotihuacán is conquered by northern tribes/Nations and begins to rapidly decline in its influence over the Mexican peoples. For two hundred years following the decline of Teotihuacán, the region has no centralized culture or political control.
Chavez kicks off the "Wrath of Grapes" campaign to draw public attention to the pesticide poisoning of grape workers and their children.

The English Assembly at Jamestown VA orders that Native American town boundaries be clearly marked and defined. This is a device whereby the whites would not have to recognize Native American title to any lands beyond the town boundaries.

U.S. Bureau of the Census states: For the first time in history, the number of biracial babies is increasing at a faster rate than the number of monoracial babies. There were 39% more Japanese/White births than monoracial Japanese American births. The number of Black/White biracial babies has increased almost 500%. In Native American communities, there are 40% more racially mixed babies than babies born to two parents who identify as Native American. 2% of all marriages or 1.2 million couples are made up of interracial relationships.

The Immigration Reform and Control Act creats an alien legalization program that brings legal status to a large number of undocumented Hispanics (amnesty to 3 million undocumented residents), and makes it illegal for employers to hire undocumented workers.

The Refugee Act of 1980 removes the definition of refugee as one who flees from a Communist regime, allowing thousands of others to enter the United States as refugees. The act provides comprehensive and uniform provisions for the effective resettlement and absorption of refugees, with up to 50,000 refugees admitted each fiscal year and emergency procedures for when that number exceeds 50,000.

The Stono Rebellion. Jemmy (a literate slave held by the Cato or Cater family in South Carolina) leads 20 other enslaved Kongolese south towards Florida where Spain was offering freedom and land in an attempt to destabilize the British colonies. They pick up other recruits along the way, burn 6 plantations and kill 23 Whites. The next day they are intercepted by a well armed mounted militia. 47 slaves are killed and the rest are sold off in the markets of the West Indies. The rebellion leads planters to increase restrictions (outlawing literacy, growing food, earning money, and other measures) while explicitly empowering Whites to examine Blacks traveling outside a plantation without papers.
6% of the U.S. population is considered Native American/Indigenous, 6.4% Hispanic – 79.6 is considered white Not Hispanic. 11.7% of the U.S. population is considered Black

The Spanish crown legalizes the distribution of Indians to work the mines as part of the encomienda system. The Native Hispaniola population of approximately 400,000 is reduced to 60,000 by 1508, and to 26,334 by 1514.
The colonial legislature in Pennsylvania, after being pressured from the Mennonites and Quakers, outlaws slavery but is overruled by the British Crown.

Anthony Johnson, a Black man, imports 5 servants and qualifies to receive a 200-acre land grant along the Puwgoteague River in Virginia. Others soon join Johnson and attempt to launch an independent African community. At its height, the settlement has 12 African homesteads with sizable holdings.
Spanish authorities raid Pueblo kivas (sacred ceremonial chambers) and destroy hundreds of Kachina masks and other sacred objects in an effort to destroy Native American “religion.”

After the decline of classic Maya culture around 900, Toltec culture begins to dominate Central America, expanding rapidly from a base at Tula in northern Mexico through Guatemala and the Yucatán peninsula. The top of their society is a warrior aristocracy that attains mythical proportions in the eyes of Central Americans long after the demise of their power. Around 1200, their dominance over the region fades.

The Congressional Black Caucus meets with President Nixon, overcoming his initial refusal by boycotting his State of the Union address and creating political pressure through press headlines. The Black members of Congress request increased attention to welfare services, desegregation, housing, and social justice programs. President Nixon reportedly promises stronger enforcement of Black civil rights laws.

The Supreme Court, in Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education, upholds busing as a legitimate means for achieving integration of public schools. Although largely unwelcome (and sometimes violently opposed) in local school districts, court-ordered busing plans in cities such as Charlotte, Boston, and Denver continue until the late 1990s.

The Maine Indian Claims Settlement Act allocates $81.5 million for the benefit of the Passamaquoddy and Penobscot, in part allowing them to purchase lands in Maine, and extinguishing all aboriginal title in Maine. The act settles the land claim, leading to recovery of more than 300,000 acres and a $27 million trust fund.

The Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services is founded in Dearborn, Michigan.  The mission of ACCESS is to "mpower communities to improve their economic, social and cultural well-being".  ACCESS helps to create the Arab American National Museum, Center for Arab American Philanthropy, and the National Network for Arab American Communities.

Vincent Chin, a 27-year-old Chinese American in Detroit, is bludgeoned to death by 2 unemployed autoworkers who blame layoffs on the Japanese and mistake Chin as Japanese. The 2 men, Robert Ebens and his stepson Michael Nitz, are sentenced to 3 years probation and fined $3000. The case becomes a rallying point for the Asian American community which overcomes inaction from traditional civil rights groups to eventually bring federal civil rights charges. In 1984, Nitz is acquitted and Ebens is sentenced to 25 years. Ebens sentence is overturned on appeal in 1986. In 1987 he is cleared of all charges. A civil suit is then settled out of court for $1.5 million, but without garnishment it is never paid off.

After California passes the Agricultural Labor Relations Act, Chavez leads a 1000 mile 59-day march to educate farm workers about their newly-won rights. The march starts from the Mexican border at San Ysidro, goes north along the coast to Salinas, then south from Sacramento down the Central Valley to the UFW headquarters at Keene.  Tens of thousands of farm workers march, attending evening rallies to hear Chavez and to organize their ranches.
Actor and radio host Casey Kasem, explains in a statement that he had to leave "Transformers" because he could not in good conscience be part of a show featuring stereotypical evil Arab characters.

The Trail of Broken Treaties, a cross-country motor caravan to advocate Native American sovereignty, ends with the occupation of the Bureau of Indian Affairs offices in Washington D.C. after discussions between officials and caravan leaders break down.

Shootout between AIM members and FBI agents on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. Two FBI agents enter the Pine Ridge Reservation claiming they are looking for a tribal member on theft and assault charges. Shots are fired under confusing circumstances, resulting in the death of two FBI agents and one AIM member. AIM activist Leonard Peltier is arrested, tried, and convicted for the deaths of the FBI agents, despite numerous continuing concerns as to the fairness of the proceedings.
Dutch occupation of north-east Brazil. "New Holland" is eventually ceded to Portugal in 1661, and the opposition to the Dutch by local Portuguese settlers lays the seeds for Brazilian nationhood.

Mississippi's NAACP field secretary, 37-year-old Medgar Evers, is murdered outside his home in Jackson, Mississipi. Byron De La Beckwith is tried twice in 1964, both trials resulting in hung juries. Thirty years later he is convicted for murdering Evers.

Jamestown starvation over the winter. Some settlers run off to join the Indians, while those remaining resort to cannibalism. The remaining settlers later demand the Indians return the runaways. When the Indians refuse, the settlers kill 15-16 adults, take the queen and her children into boats and kill them.

Santos Rodriguez and his brother David (12 and 13 years old) are pulled from their home by police, handcuffed, placed in a police car, and accused of stealing $8 from a gas station vending machine. One of the officers plays Russian roulette with Santos who insists he is telling the truth about not being involved. The officer shoots Santos and kills him. The Mexican-American community organizes a peaceful protest, but it turns violent with damage to police property, injuries and arrests. The need for change is recognized by the city. Over the next 40 years Dallas increases the percentage of non-white police officers and creates a citizen's police review board.

French and Indian War. The North American theater of the worldwide Seven Years War pits British colonies against French colonies with both sides supported by their parent countries and Native American allies. In the end, France cedes claims to all lands west of the Mississippi to Spain. Overnight, New Spain's territory expands dramatically
Danny Thomas, a Christian Lebanese born as Amos Kairouz, founds St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee. Thomas was also a comedian, singer and television actor.

Benjamin Banneker, a 22-year old free Black man, builds a striking wooden clock from scratch using only a borrowed pocket watch as a model. He teaches himself mathematics and astronomy, accurately predicting a solar eclipse. In a letter to Thomas Jefferson he requests readers "wean yourselves from those narrow prejudices which you have imbibed". Banneker's accomplishments and writings become legendary.
Gallup Poll finds that more Americans (48%) approve of interracial marriage than disapprove (42%)

United States Declaration of Independence. The amended form is adopted, which does not include Jefferson’s proposal denouncing slavery. The rationales for separation include a statement that the King is inciting Indian attacks. The revolutionary war had already grown from active resistance in 1773 to open combat in 1775. The war continues until 1783.
César Chavez founds the National Farm Workers Association (NFWA), to organize impoverished migrant farm laborers in California.

The Lieutenant-Governor of Massachusetts, seeking to elminate all Penobscot Indians, offers £40 for each male scalp and £20 for each female or child scalp. Rewards for capture are only marginally higher. £40 is over $6,000 today.

The 1990 U.S. Census shows a high percentage of Arab men (79%) and women (73%) are intermarried. The first wave of Arab Americans included individuals from countries that were facing religious persecution, such as Christians. Since these Arabs had fair skin, blond hair and blue eyes, they had an easier time being accepted by the dominant groups in American culture.

By 1800, the number of Native Americans had been reduced to about 600,000, due to policies of forced displacement and war. The white population of the U.S., however, increased to over 6 million in 1810, and the black population reached approximately one and half million.

President Carter signs the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA), protecting the integrity of Native American families by eliminating child welfare practices that result in unwarranted Native American parent-child separations. By this Act, Nations/tribes are given the authority to care for Native American children, to intercede in court cases regarding adoptive placement of Native American children, and to place Native American children with tribal members or with members of other Nations/tribes.

Patrick Purdy fires 105 rounds from an assault rifle at children in an elementary schoolyard in Stockton California, killing five Southeast Asian children and wounding 30 others before killing himself with a pistol.

The “Walking Purchase Treaty” is signed by Pennyslvania colonists and Delaware’s Lappawinzo, Nutimus, and Sassoonan. According to convention, land was ceded by the Native Americans in terms of the distance a man could walk in a day. The English used trained ”walkers” who covered 67 miles in a day and a half, a distance far in excess of the Delawares’ intent.

President Johnson presents Annie Dodge Wauneka with the Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian award, for her accomplishments in eradicating tuberculosis among Native people. To date, she is the first and only Native American so honored.

Aided by some of the Shawnee, the English in South Carolina destroy all but fifty of their allies, the Westos, in order to get slaves and better access to the interior. The survivors eventually join the Muscogee (Creek).

The report of the Commission of Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians, a committee investigating the WWII internment, is released. It concludes that exclusion, expulsion, and incarceration were not justified by military necessity and that the decision was based on race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership.

Fearing the Naragansett will side with Metacomet in the spring, colonial militia attack the Great Swamp fort near Kingston, Rhode Island. In addition to killing Naragansett warriors, the militia destroy winter stores and kill hundreds of women and children.

King Phillips War. The fragile peace negotiated between the Wampanoag confederacy led by Massasoit and the Pilgrims led by William Bradford falls apart from disease pandemics and disregard from boatloads of new arrivals.  Metacomet, second son of Massasoit (also called Metacom and by his adopted English name King Philip), gathers some 20,000 Native Americans who fight for a year against the New England colonists, but fail to win back their country. The war is one of the bloodiest and most costly in the history of America. One in ten soldiers on both sides are injured or killed. Hundreds of Natives who fought with Philip are sold into slavery abroad, others (especially women and children) are forced into servitude locally.
Chavez calls for a nationwide boycott of non-union lettuce. Later this year, he is jailed in Salinas, Calif. for refusing to obey a court order to stop the boycott against Bud Antle lettuce.
58 cases of hate crimes against South Asian Indians are reported in New Jersey, despite tougher anti-hate crime laws passed the previous year.

The Treaty of Lancaster. Virginia and Maryland colonies convince the Haudenosaunee Confederacy (aka the "Six Nations" or Iroquois) to surrender their land to the "setting sun". The Confederacy interprets this as the crest of the Alleghenies and the British colonies interpret it as all of western Virginia. Following King George's War in 1748 between England and France, Virginia pioneers push west of the Alleghenies.
English ships visit the New England coast, trading with and sometimes kidnapping Algonquins.

The first U.S. treaty with Native Americans (the Lenape - Delaware) recognizing the rights of Native Americans to land they occupy. The Department of State recognizes a total of 375 instruments. The earliest is "The Great Treaty of 1722 Between the Five Nations, the Mahicans, and the Colonies of New York, Virginia, and Pennsylvania". The last is in 1869, forcing Chief Joseph and his Nez Perce people off their lands.
The Indian Arts & Crafts Act prohibits misrepresentation in marketing of American Indian or Alaska Native arts and crafts products within the United States.
Quakers importing slaves are threatened with expulsion from the society.

Chavín urban culture (so-called because its major site was found in the area of Chavín de Huantar) arises in the highlands of northern Peru and thrives until 500 BCE. Little is known about the Chavín, but they worshipped a jaguar-man god like the Olmecs, so there might have been some kind of cultural contact between the two. After the decline of the Chavín civilization, the Andean regions continued to be dominated by local urban cultures
ASPIRA is founded to promote the education of Hispanic youth by raising public and private sector funds.

Traders begin to use distilled liquor (fire water) to entice agreements. While many Native American Nations/tribes produced mild fermented beverages for ceremonial purposes, they had no distilled liquor and very little time to adapt to what colonists were quite used to. There are no current discovered genetic or other biological anomalies that render Native peoples particularly vulnerable to alcoholism.

The English, French, and Spanish all try to win over the Creek Confederacy (Muscogee) to secure their trade, but the Creek declare themselves neutral with respect to colonial rivalries and maintain a balance of power.

Huari-Tiahuanaco culture begins to dominate the Andean region and enforce cultural conformity through the Middle Horizon period (600-1000). Scholars believe that the architecture and the social and political structure of the Incas ultimately derive from Huari-Tiahuanaco.
The US invasion of Santo Domingo during the Dominican Civil War marks the beginning of a massive migration to the US.
The descendents and community of Wounded Knee victims erect a memorial at the grave site.

The Japanese American Citizen League (JACL) joins with organizations including SAALT in objecting to hearings on “The Extent of Radicalization in the American Muslim Community” in the U.S. House of Representatives targeting South Asian, Arab, Sikh, and Muslim Americans. Instead, they call on Congress to engage in objective dialogue about national security.
18.9 Million U.S. residents identify as Asian or Asian with a combination of another race. This composes 5.6% of the total population.
Viking publishes, “Where the Lightning Strikes: The Lives of American Indian Sacred Places,” by Peter Nabokov.

The Platt Amendment, passed as part of the Army Appropriations Bill, specifies seven conditions for the withdrawal of U.S. troops that must be accepted by Cuba. The agreement establishes U.S. dominance over Cuba and allows for U.S. military installations.
Foreign policy advisor, Susan Rice, becomes first African American woman to be the United States UN ambassador

The “Quincy 4”. Four Chinese Americans in Quincy Massachusetts who are involved in a verbal argument are brutally arrested and charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest. After accusing the police of using excessive force, they are found guilty and imprisoned for 10 days despite inconsistencies in testimony and an eyewitness to the unprovoked use of pepper spray by a Quincy police officer.
Nuclear bombs are dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Japan surrenders.

President Obama signs legislation funding legal settlements with Black farmers and Native Americans. $1.15 billion is allocated for the settlement of the 1997 Pigford v. Glickman case against the U.S. Agriculture Department over claims of discrimination against Black farmers in the allocation of farm loans and assistance. $3.4 billion is allocated for the settlement reached with the Department of Interior for mishandling Native American trust funds, along with four separate water rights lawsuits brought by Native American tribes.
Congress passes civil rights legislation guaranteeing equal rights to Black Americans in public accommodations and jury duty. The legislation is invalidated by the Supreme Court in 1883

Cumberland County Senior Resident Superior Court Judge Gregory Weeks issues the first decision under North Carolina’s Racial Justice Act. He rules that there was racial bias against Marcus Robinson during his 1991 trial. Despite the ruling made by Weeks, the State legislature passes measures weakening the racial Justice Act.

The United States Board on Geographic names admits that names with ‘squaw’ in them are offensive and finally agrees to change names in Grant County Oregon. The Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation fought against white officials for years to change the names.

The Harlem Renaissance. The Harlem neighborhood of NYC becomes the center of new African-American cultural expressions across urban areas in the Northeast and Midwest United States. It is an astonishing period of creativity for Black writers, poets and artists. The cultural impact is worldwide.
1.5 Million businesses are owned by Asian Americans, up 40% from 2002.

The Chinese community organizes to challenge the constitutionality of the Geary Act before the Supreme Court. In upholding the act, the Supreme Court decides in the case of Fong Yue Ting v. United States, that the Congress has the right to legislate expulsion of Chinese through the order of executive officers.
The Confederación de Uniones Obreras Mexicanas (Federation of Mexican Workers Union-CUOM) in Los Angeles is formed, the first large-scale effort to organize and consolidate Mexican workers.
Blanche Kelso Bruce (Republican) of Mississippi becomes the first African American to serve a full six-year term. Not until 1969 will another Black American begin a Senate term.

A Republican political rally in downtown Clinton, Mississippi is disrupted by white insurgents. Armed whites arrive by train and kill an estimated 50 blacks over the next two days including schoolteachers, church leaders, and local Republican organizers. Election-related violence continues through the fall enabling white Democrats to gain control of the state legislature.

One of the bloodiest race riots in the nation’s history takes place in East St. Louis. An estimated 40-200 people are killed, hundreds more injured, and 6,000 driven from their homes. Marcus Garvey describes the riot as a "wholesale massacre of our people".

Oklahoma governor’s daughter Christina Fallin publicizes a photo of herself wearing a Native American headdress with the caption “appropriate culturation” which was a play on words for promotion of her new song about to release. The Native American community feels targeted and is outraged. Fallin apologizes in a press conference, but it feels like an empty declaration, making the community more distraught.
Michael Brown is fatally shot in Ferguson, Missouri. The unarmed 18-year old African American man is shot at by a White officer after a shop lifting event.
Mariah Idrissi, who is half Moroccan, becomes the first hijab-wearing model featured by H&M, the second largest retailer in the world.

My Brother’s Keeper”, is launched by President Obama. This initiative aims to improve the lives of young boys and men of color by offering better opportunities, as well as aiding in better life outcomes. $200 Million dollars will be donated by ten different investment firms over the next five years.
Eric Garner is choked to death by New York police.
Japan declares Korea its colony.
The Native American Church, blending Native American and Christian spirituality and using peyote, is organized and spreads rapidly. It advocates family cooperation and pan-Native American unity.

The White House releases Empowering Local Partners to Prevent Violent Extremism in the United States, the first national strategy to prevent violent extremism domestically. The underlying premise of the approach to Countering Violent Extremism (CVE) in the United States is that (1) communities provide the solution to violent extremism; and (2) CVE efforts are best pursued at the local level, tailored to local dynamics, where local officials continue to build relationships within their communities through established community policing and community outreach mechanisms. The pilot programs for CVE are in Greater Boston, Los Angeles, and the Twin Cities.

54% of African Americans claim to be victims in bullying scenarios compared to the 44% of white correspondents in a Workplace Bullying Survey. An example of this bullying made headlines when two current and two former African American employees sued Daimler trucks North America, in Portland Oregon. The African American men claimed that a dozen White employees threatened them with physical violence, graffiti of “hangman’s nooses” drawn on lockers, as well as placing rotten food in the back of their lockers.

The Johnson-Reed Act, including the Asian Exclusion Act and the National Origins Act, outright bans immigration of people from Asia, the Polynesian Islands, and the Middle East. Quotas severely restrict the immigration of Africans, along with eastern and southern Europeans. The purpose of the act is "to preserve the ideal of American homogeneity"
President Obama appoints Peter M. Rouse as interim Chief of Staff, the first Asian American to hold this position.

The "Five Civilized Tribes" - the Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek (Muscogee), and Seminole - are granted U.S. citizenship. The driving force is to have enough votes in Oklahoma Territory to gain statehood.

The U.S. Supreme Court rules against two school districts voluntarily using individualized racial classifications to achieve diversity and/or avoid racial isolation.  In Parents Involved in Community Schools v. Seattle School District No. 1 (aka the "PICS" case) the Court finds the assignment plans are not sufficiently "narrowly tailored".
Hawaii is incorporated as a territory of the U.S. but Chinese living in Hawaii are forbidden to travel to the U.S. mainland.
Seung-Hui Cho, a Korean American student at Virginia Tech, shoots and kills 32 people, wounds many others, then commits suicide.

Angel Island in the San Francisco Bay is set up as a detention center for non-laboring Asian immigrants. Over the next 30 years, hopeful Chinese immigrants are detained at Angel island where they are required to undergo medical examinations and detailed interrogations. Failed answers are grounds for continued detainment and eventual deportation back to China. Some detainees commit suicide.
Civil rights leader and wife of Martin Luther King, Jr., Coretta Scott King, dies at age 78
Census indicates that 21 percent of the Black population is of visible mixed race.

California’s KTVU broadcasted a segment on fake names of the pilots following the crash of Asiana Airlines flight 214 in which 3 people died and 187 people were injured. These names were “Sum Ting Wong” “Wi Tu Lo” “Ho Lee Fuk” and “Bang Ding Ow”. To add insult to injury, the flight’s name was dubbed Fright 214 in media coverage. Turning this tragedy into a comedy funded by racial slurs, and offensive jokes, was disheartening to people affected by the plane crash.

Edith Maude Eaton, also known as Sui Sin Far, dies. The daughter of a Chinese mother and British father, she was a writer who created stories (during the early 1900s) sympathetic to the Chinese and multi-racial Chinese in the U.S.

The “Day without immigrants” protest is organized. Hundreds of thousands of Latino immigrants and supporters boycott work, school, and shopping to illustrate the necessity of the contributions of immigrants.

First meeting of the Niagara movement, a group of African American intellectuals and activists, led by W. E. B.
